IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: TO HELP DONORS ENGAGE IN STRATEGIC CONSERVATION ENDEAVORS THAT HAVE LASTING VALUE.
IRS990.MissionDesc: RESOURCES LEGACY FUND HELPS DONORS ENSURE THE PROTECTION AND STEWARDSHIP OF RESILIENT AND VIBRANT NATURAL SYSTEMS THAT SUPPORT HEALTHY COMMUNITIES AND ECONOMIC VITALITY.
IRS990.Desc: DURING THE LAST YEAR, RESOURCES LEGACY FUND (RLF) CARRIED OUT PROGRAMS AND AWARDED GRANTS TO SUPPORT ACTIVITIES THAT WORK TO IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY IN WESTERN NORTH AMERICA AS WELL AS IN OCEANS AND FISHERIES WORLDWIDE. SELECT RLF ACCOMPLISHMENTS DURING 2015 INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING:RLF COORDINATED AND SUPPORTED THE EARLY 2015 COMPLETION OF A PUBLIC PROCESS FOR DEVELOPING A PLAN FOR ENSURING THE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF CALIFORNIA'S STATE PARKS. THE PLAN RESULTED FROM MORE THAN 18 MONTHS OF RESEARCH, OUTREACH, AND COORDINATION BETWEEN A PUBLICLY APPOINTED COMMISSION, KEY STATE AGENCIES, AND THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE GOVERNOR OF CALIFORNIA. IT DETAILED A FUNDAMENTAL TRANSFORMATION OF THE STATE'S PARK SYSTEM, AND RECOMMENDED MAJOR CHANGES TO MODERNIZE THE SYSTEM, ENGAGE PARTNERS, AND EXPAND ACCESS. AFTER THE PLAN'S COMPLETION, RLF CONTINUED TO WORK WITH THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION TO IMPLEMENT THE RECOMMENDATIONS THROUGH THE DEPARTMENT'S TRANSFORMATION INITIATIVE.RLF LAUNCHED THE CALIFORNIA DROUGHT ACTION INITIATIVE-COMPRISING A RANGE OF TARGETED OUTREACH AND EDUCATION EFFORTS-WITH THE AIM USING DROUGHT-AMPLIFIED PUBLIC AND DECISION-MAKER ATTENTION TO ADVANCE CHANGES IN HOW THE STATE MANAGES ITS WATER. THIS INCLUDED SUPPORTING EFFORTS TO (1) DRIVE CREATION OF A ROBUST, STATEWIDE WATER MARKET BY ESTABLISHING A COMPREHENSIVE AND ACCESSIBLE WATER DATA SYSTEM; (2) SECURE SUSTAINABLE FUNDING FOR DEVELOPMENT OF NEW LOCAL WATER SOURCES SUCH AS CAPTURED STORMWATER AND RECYCLED WASTEWATER; AND (3) ENSURE THAT ALL CALIFORNIA COMMUNITIES HAVE ADEQUATE, SUSTAINABLE, AND AFFORDABLE SUPPLIES OF SAFE DRINKING WATER. TO PROMOTE SUSTAINABLE FISHERIES WORLDWIDE, RLF PROVIDED SUPPORT TO OVERCOME FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL OBSTACLES TO FISHERY AND STAKEHOLDER PARTICIPATION IN THE MARINE STEWARDSHIP COUNCIL (MSC) FISHERY CERTIFICATION PROGRAM. FOR EXAMPLE, RLF GRANTS SUPPORTED MULTI-FISHERY PRE-ASSESSMENTS IN FRANCE, SPAIN, ICELAND, AND JAMAICA; DESIGN OF FISHERY IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS FOR SEVEN SMALL-SCALE FISHERIES IN BRAZIL; AND TESTING OF A CAPACITY BUILDING TOOLKIT FOR DEVELOPING INTERNATIONAL STAKEHOLDERS SEEKING TO ENGAGE IN FISHERY IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS ALIGNED WITH THE MSC STANDARD. IN ADDITION, TO ENABLE FISHERIES MANAGED BY THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA TO MEET GLOBAL STANDARDS FOR MANAGEMENT AND SUSTAINABILITY, RLF SUPPORTED THE TESTING OF TOOLS FOR ANALYZING THE STATUS AND PERFORMANCE OF CALIFORNIA FISHERIES; DEVELOPMENT OF MORE EFFECTIVE APPROACHES TO STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT; AND SCOPING AN ASSESSMENT OF STATE FISHERIES DATA COLLECTION, MANAGEMENT, AND ANALYSIS PROGRAMS.RLF WORKED WITH THE SAN FRANCISCO BAYLANDS STEERING COMMITTEE, MANAGING A PUBLIC EDUCATION CAMPAIGN, OUR BAY ON THE BRINK, TO INFORM THE PUBLIC ABOUT SIGNIFICANT ENVIRONMENTAL THREATS TO THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AND POTENTIAL SOLUTIONS. USING TARGETED DIGITAL MEDIA, EARNED MEDIA, BILLBOARDS, AND MAIL, THE OUTREACH CAMPAIGN INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF FLOOD AND SEA LEVEL RISE IMPACTS AS WELL AS THREATS TO WILDLIFE AND COMMUNITIES.IN NORTHWEST MEXICO, RLF SUPPORTED THE PROTECTION OF 14,033 STRATEGICALLY TARGETED ACRES, AS WELL AS GRANTEE ACTIVITIES THAT IMPLEMENTED COMPLEMENTARY ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY, COMMUNICATION, SCIENCE, AND OTHER STRATEGIES TO ADVANCE CONSERVATION IN THE REGION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: RLF HAS APPLIED THE ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES RELATED TO ACCOUNTING FOR UNCERTAINTY IN INCOME TAXES AND HAS DETERMINED THAT THERE IS NO MATERIAL IMPACT ON THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS. WITH SOME EXCEPTIONS, RLF IS NO LONGER SUBJECT TO U.S. FEDERAL OR STATE INCOME TAX EXAMINATIONS BY TAX AUTHORITIES FOR YEARS PRIOR TO 2011.

AccountActivitiesOutsideUSGrp.RegionTxt: CENTRAL AMERICA AND THE CARIBBEAN - ANTIGUA & BARBUDA, ARUBA, BAHAMAS,

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: WHEN GRANTING TO A NON-U.S. BASED CONSERVATION ORGANIZATION, RLF REQUIRES DOCUMENTATION FROM THE APPLICANT THAT ESTABLISHES AND DESCRIBES THAT ORGANIZATION'S LEGAL STATUS, PURPOSE, AND MISSION, AND OFTEN REQUIRES THIRD-PARTY LETTERS OF REFERENCE. ADDITIONALLY, RLF CONFIRMS THAT THE POTENTIAL GRANTEE AND PRINCIPALS DO NOT APPEAR ON THE TREASURY DEPARTMENT'S SPECIALLY DESIGNATED NATIONALS (SDN). RLF ALSO REQUIRES GRANTEES EITHER TO ESTABLISH AND MAINTAIN A DESIGNATED BANK ACCOUNT FOR THE GRANT FUNDS, OR RECORD AND MAINTAIN THE GRANT FUNDS IN A SEPARATE BOOKKEEPING ACCOUNT. RLF OFTEN PROVIDES GRANT FUNDING TO U.S.-BASED 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATIONS WITH OFFICES IN OTHER COUNTRIES TO WORK WITH NON-U.S. ORGANIZATIONS IN ORDER TO MONITOR THE PROJECT AND WORK TO ENSURE THAT FUNDING IS EFFECTIVELY USED FOR ITS INTENDED PURPOSE. ALL RLF GRANTS INCLUDE REQUIREMENTS FOR PERIODIC REPORTS RECONCILING GRANT ACTIVITIES, PROGRESS, AND OUTCOMES WITH GRANT OBJECTIVES, AS WELL AS A RECONCILIATION OF GRANT EXPENDITURES TO THE PROPOSAL BUDGET.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: ALL RLF GRANTS INCLUDE REQUIREMENTS FOR PERIODIC REPORTS RECONCILING GRANT ACTIVITIES, PROGRESS, AND OUTCOMES WITH GRANT OBJECTIVES, AS WELL AS A RECONCILIATION OF GRANT EXPENDITURES WITH THE PROPOSAL BUDGET. IN ADDITION, STAFF MAINTAINS CONTACT WITH GRANTEES AND PERIODICALLY CONDUCTS FIELD VISITS FOR SIGNIFICANT PROJECTS.

BusTrInvolveInterestedPrsnGrp.RelationshipDescriptionTxt: RLG IS OWNED BY MICHAEL MANTELL (PRESIDENT) & MARY SCOONOVER (SECRETARY)
BusTrInvolveInterestedPrsnGrp.TransactionDesc: RLF ENTERED INTO AGREEMENTS WITH RLG FOR THE CAPITAL LEASE OF FURNITURE AND FOR SHARED RESOURCES OF STAFF, OFFICE SERVICES, AND TECHNOLOGY RESOURCES. RLF ALSO SUBLEASES OFFICE SPACE FROM RLG AND PAYS MONTHLY RENT AND PARKING DIRECTLY TO THE LANDLORD BASED ON ITS PROPORTIONATE SHARE OF SPACE. RLG REIMBURSED RLF $143,900 FOR THE COST OF SHARED SERVICES AND RLF PAID RLG $73,300 UNDER A CAPITAL LEASE AGREEMENT, FOR A NET AMOUNT OF $70,600 TO RLF.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION A, LINE 2
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: MICHAEL MANTELL, MARY SCOONOVER, AND SHAUNA MANNER ARE OFFICERS OF RLF AND HAVE A BUSINESS RELATIONSHIP - MICHAEL AND MARY ARE OWNERS OF RESOURCES LAW GROUP (RLG) AND SHAUNA IS EMPLOYED BY RLG.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION A, LINE 4
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE ORGANIZATION MADE THE FOLLOWING CHANGES TO ITS BYLAWS: - INCREASED THE MAXIMUM NUMBER OF DIRECTORS FROM 11 TO 15 - CHANGED THE QUORUM REQUIREMENT FROM 1/5 TO 1/3 OF THE AUTHORIZED NUMBER OF DIRECTORS OR 2 DIRECTORS, WHICHEVER IS LARGER - EXTENDED THE COMPENSATION DETERMINATION REQUIREMENT TO THE CFO.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 11
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE 990 IS PREPARED BY OUTSIDE TAX ACCOUNTANTS, REVIEWED BY THE CONTROLLER, CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER, THE PRESIDENT OF RESOURCES LEGACY FUND, AND THE AUDIT COMMITTEE. IT IS THEN SENT TO ALL VOTING MEMBERS BEFORE FILING.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 12C
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: A CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY COVERS OFFICERS AND DIRECTORS, WHO ARE REQUIRED TO DISCLOSE POTENTIAL CONFLICTS ANNUALLY IN WRITING. THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS DETERMINES IF AN ACTUAL CONFLICT EXISTS AND IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY REQUIRED REVIEW AND ACTION. ADDITIONALLY, A CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY IS INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEE POLICY MANUAL. UPON HIRE, EMPLOYEES ARE REQUIRED TO READ IT AND ACKNOWLEDGE THAT THEY ARE FAMILIAR WITH AND WILL OBSERVE THE POLICY.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE GOVERNANCE COMMITTEE, ON BEHALF OF THE BOARD, ENGAGED AN OUTSIDE CONSULTANT TO REVIEW THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION OF RLF'S PEERS, TO ASSESS RLF'S EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION, AND TO PROVIDE AN INDEPENDENT OPINION REGARDING THE REASONABLENESS OF RLF'S EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION. THE POSITIONS OF PRESIDENT, EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, AND CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER WERE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSESSMENT. THIS PROCESS WAS LAST UNDERTAKEN IN 2015. ON A BI-ANNUAL BASIS, THE PRESIDENT REVIEWS COMPENSATION SURVEY DATA AND COMPENSATION DATA FROM SEVERAL SIMILAR ORGANIZATIONS, COMBINES IT WITH HIS AWARENESS OF COMPENSATION PRACTICES GAINED THROUGH HIS PROFESSIONAL AND VOLUNTEER AFFILIATIONS, AND ESTABLISHES A REASONABLE COMPENSATION LEVEL FOR THE KEY EMPLOYEES. THIS PROCESS WAS LAST UNDERTAKEN IN 2015

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION C, LINE 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: AUDITED STATEMENTS AND 990 TAX RETURNS ARE AVAILABLE AND DOWNLOADABLE FROM WWW.RESOURCESLEGACYFUND.ORG. ORGANIZATIONAL BY-LAWS AND IRS LETTER OF DETERMINATION OF TAX EXEMPTION ARE PROVIDED AT REQUEST TO ALL DONORS.
CONSULTING FEES: PROGRAM SERVICE EXPENSES 8,692,814. MANAGEMENT AND GENERAL EXPENSES 38,885. FUNDRAISING EXPENSES 0. TOTAL EXPENSES 8,731,699.

FEES INCLUDE PAYMENTS TO OVER 65 VENDORS FOR SCIENTIFIC STUDIES, STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS, MAPPING, CONSERVATION EXPERTISE, PROGRAM DESIGN, MANAGEMENT AND EVALUATION, PREPARATION OF ENVRIONMENTAL DOCUMENTS REQUIRED FOR PROJECTS BY GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES, AND POLICY RESEARCH AND ANALYSIS.
NEITHER PROCESS HAS CHANGED FROM THE PRIOR YEAR.

IdRelatedTaxExemptOrgGrp.PrimaryActivitiesTxt: SUPPORTING ORG FOR RESOURCES LEGACY FUND
